Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Commercialization Feasibility Of an In-situ Sensor For Vehicular Impact Monitoring System
Award.AbstractNarration:
Inadequate vertical clearance is listed as a leading cause of accidents involving highway bridges in many States. In addition, state bridge engineers list over-height loads as the leading cause of damages to pre-stressed concrete bridges. As rampant and destructive as over-height vehicle collisions are, there is no technology in use for monitoring vehicle collisions on our bridges. In fact, very few states collect data on bridge hits. Very significant maintenance budget savings can be achieved if over-height vehicle collisions can be prevented with an effective monitoring system.

In this proposal, the team has developed the In-situ Triboluminescent Optical Fiber (ITOF) sensor. This proposed technology is an integrated sensing and signal transmission sensor system that can function as a triboluminescent optical nerve analogous to the nerves in mammals. The ITOF system may be readily integrated into large civil and aerospace structures to provide in-situ, distributed and real time damage monitoring. The ITOF sensor combines the highly desirable features of polymer optical fibers (POF) such as lightweight, smaller sizes, immunity to electromagnetic interference and capacity for distributed sensing with the triboluminescent (TL) property of ZnS:Mn. The ITOF sensor has an integrated sensing (triboluminescence sensory receptor) and transmission component (polymer optical fiber) that converts the energy from damage events like impacts and crack propagation into optical signals that are indicative of the magnitude of damage in composite structures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on determining the commercial feasibility of the innovative in-situ triboluminescent optical fiber (ITOF) sensor technology. Two key application areas were studied namely: composite airplanes and wind turbine blades. Over a hundred interviews were conducted with about 60 being in-person interviews. The team conducted in-person interviews in Tallahassee and Orlando, Florida. In Texas, the team conducted in-person interviews in Austin, Lubbock, and Merkel where the team visited the seventh largest wind farm in the world.

After 50 interviews involving speaking to technical experts and business leaders in the aircraft and wind energy sectors, the team realized that the strict regulation and high liability of the aircraft industry would result in very slow adoption of the technology in that industry. The team also learned that there is a real need for in-situ damage monitoring system in wind blades. More importantly, the sensor technology has the potential to provide real time load profile of the wind blade. Such load information can be fed into the turbine control system for active control of the wind turbine. This capability can actually help to prevent damage of the blade and other expensive components such as bearings and gear boxes. In addition, according to experts, it can result to about 20 percent increase in wind turbine electricity production translating to huge revenue for wind farm owners. The sensor technology can make smart wind farm possible thereby making wind energy more cost effective and more attractive to investors, while also reducing the harmful effects of energy production from fossil fuels on the environment.

Based on the successful commercial feasibility study from the NSF I-Corps program, a technology startup company (Nanotechnology Patronas Group Inc., aka NPGroup) submitted a proposal for NSF STTR I funding to demonstrate proof of concept of the ITOF as a load sensor for active control of wind turbines. The company has the NSF I-Corps Team 377 Entrepreneurial Lead as the CEO. The proposal has been recommended for funding and the project will kick off in January 2016. The company is about concluding licensing agreement with Florida State University for the use of the triboluminescent sensor technology invented by two of the company founders.

 


Last Modified: 11/18/2015
Modified by: Okenwa O Okoli
